Thoughts on MassTransit on other languages

Posted by Dru Sellers on August 21, 2011

This weekend I sat in another nodejs talk, I found myself thinking again about how I would implement mass transit in other languages; specifically those that are not statically typed. The typical use of masstransit in .net looks like this.

bus.Subscribe<Ping>(msg =>
{
    // do stuff with the ping message
});

What this does is instruct the bus to subscribe to the message named ‘Ping’ and when that message arrives it then passes it to the handler (that’s the anonymous function). Because .Net is both statically and strongly typed I know that they want a ping message, just by looking at the type name. MassTransit also has a bunch of code to handle routing that is also influenced on the type of the message. But in JavaScript I don’t have that luxury in the same way. Â in javascript you might say:

bus.subscribe('ping', function(msg) {

/* do stuff */

});

So we don’t have a type name to key off of, only a string name. As someone that has learned to use every last scrap of metadata in my programming language its very bizarre to switch to a language that has so much LESS metadata available to me. I could try to improve that a bit with a constant so it would look like

bus.subscribe(MessageNames.ping, function(msg) {

/* do stuff */

});

Which does feel better, but its weird to me that its not as ‘tight’ as the .net experience. But then again, that is the whole point of dynamic languages, a dynamic environment.

The more that I ponder on it, the more I wonder if its just that I don’t have the patterns of thought necessary to structure large applications in non-static languages. what i need is a new way to derive the ‘name’ of the message in JavaScript. I am not content with the simplistic ‘string’ approach. I wonder if I can also apply the powerful concept of object scoping to mass transit in JS in the same fashion that we do in the .net version as well. I should be able to, there is an amazing amount of object scoping in the best practices of JS.

//module pattern

(function(global, bus) {
    //could auto register handlers using a known convention
    bus.loadFrom(global);
    bus.subscribe('msg name', function (msg) {
    }); // for one offs
})(window, busInstance);

Ok, I like that quite a bit. Not sure if the global is needed or not. I wonder what that would look like in CoffeeScript (tries for a bit and falls on face, must try later). I wonder if I could then do some magic around require.js or some other dependency resolver to complete the magic. Hmmmâ¦.

Overall I am much happier now. I am starting to see how I could use javascript in much the same fashion, I have identified some patterns of use that I would like to attack and better understand around versioning as well. Of course a lot of this is just academic for me, I still need a real problem to solve.

Happy Sunday

-d

Sr. Software Engineer at Dovetail Software.

    You can still use typeof in javascript.

    function foo() { }

    function subscribe(type, callback) { … }

    function send(msg) {
    Â  for(var i in callbacks) {
    Â  Â if(callbacks[i].type == typeof msg) {
    Â  Â  callbacks[i].callback(msg);
    Â  Â }
    Â  }
    }

    That code is probably not totally right, but basically you can still use typeof to get you more strong-typey-ness if you wanted.

    Though I don’t see anything wrong with the string approach. The type is basically just a string too at the bottom.

    I’m not familiar with how MassTransit works, but other buses I’ve looked at have just used the generic type as aÂ convenientÂ way to avoid using strings; but ultimately it’s a string which gets used as the routing key, and somewhere down the line type.Name gets called. Why are you not content with using a string, when that’s really what it boils down to even in .Net? (Excuse my ignorance)

  • Chris Bristol

    To me, a lot of it comes down to the different mentalities you have to have when using a static vs. dynamic language. Â One of the great things about a static language is that a large number of errors can be identified at compile time. It is much more difficult (if not nearly impossible) to register something on the bus which would cause a failure. Using generics, the compiler can guarantee:
    1. Ping is a sub-type of some sort of Message base class/interface (if necessary)
    2. The provided handler function accepts a Ping as an argument
    3. The provided handler function returns the appropriate type of result (if any)
    4. The handler registration and retrieval code is synchronized. I will never retrieve a handler for a message other than a Ping message when I ask for all of the Ping message handlers.A dynamic language doesn’t really give you that, almost all failures are delayed until run time, which puts a lot of pressure on good testing. Â Nothing is fixed in place, and therefore you can’t tell if something is going to succeed until after its done. Â This kind of programming is definitely useful; I don’t think a strongly typed language could even come close to matching JavaScript when it comes to handling various browser inconsistencies.At some point, you have to accept that programming in a dynamic language is a different beast. Â A much looser, more flexible beast. Â To some extent, you tradeÂ predictabilityÂ forÂ flexibility.

    With that said, I think a string-based approach is perfectly valid in a dynamic language. However, I reserve the right to think its terrible in a language where more powerful tools are available. Â When you choose a language, you choose its strengths and its weaknesses, and I think this is an area where statically typed, managed languages win pretty convincingly.

  • Anonymous
